stories.story: I remember the day we finished the Thompson Community Center. The whole crew stood outside, admiring the brickwork, and I handed the keys to the mayor. My son was there, just starting out, and I showed him the foundation—solid, level, built to last. That building was more than concrete and steel; it was a promise to the neighborhood. I still drive by sometimes, just to see it standing strong.

There was a day, years ago, when we finished the community center. The crew gathered outside, and I gave the keys to the mayor. My son was with me, learning the ropes. That building meant a lot to us all.
I remember finishing a building—a community center, I think. The crew was proud. My son was there. We handed over the keys. It felt important.
There was a day, a building, a crew. My son was there. We finished the job. I remember feeling proud.
A building. Crew. My son. We finished.
